headline.main: LATEST BY TELEGRAPH.; FROM WASHINGTON. Important Insructions to Minister Forsyth. Cabinet Movements--Opposition to Collector Sebell's Appointment--Official Accounts of Col-Steptoe's Defeat--Lieut. Ives' Expendition, &c.

docs.abstract: Found guilty by the Court Martial
docs.lead_paragraph: I have it from a reliable source that the State Department has issued instructions to Mr. FORSYTH under no circumstances to abandon his post, but to enter a protest against all improper acts of the Government of Mexico towards citizens of the United States. These acts will be regarded by the Administration as so much capital invested towards the purchase of Sonora and Cinaloa.

docs.snippet: Much alarm is felt in the towns adjoining Middletown, Conn., on account of the prevalence of the small-pox in that city. As usual, there is a great deal of exaggeration in the reports. In Middletown papers we see a statement from the Board of Health,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Much alarm is felt in the towns adjoining Middletown, Conn., on account of the prevalence of the small-pox in that city. As usual, there is a great deal of exaggeration in the reports. In Middletown papers we see a statement from the Board of Health, that only ten cases of variolaid and small-pox are known in the town, and some of these are very slight.

docs.abstract: Action of the Board of Health
docs.lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President ?? the Chain. Petitions were received in relation to frauds in Washington Marke, and were referred to the Committee having that matter in charge. A resolution in inquiry into the cause why the contract for ?? railing for Pompki?? square has not been vertised for by the Street Commissioner was offered by Alberman BOOLE.

headline.main: UTAH.; Gen. Johnston to the War Department. Proclamation of Gen. Johnston to the People of Utah. Dispatches from Gen. Johnston and the Peace Commissioners.

docs.snippet: We give, in this morning's TIMES, several important documents from Utah. A dispatch from Gen. JOHNSTON to the War Department, dated at Bear River, June 16, states that the Army, which was on its march from Fort Bridger to Great Salt Lake City, would...
docs.lead_paragraph: We give, in this morning's TIMES, several important documents from Utah. A dispatch from Gen. JOHNSTON to the War Department, dated at Bear River, June 16, states that the Army, which was on its march from Fort Bridger to Great Salt Lake City, would probably reach its destination on the 22d.

headline.main: CENTRAL AMERICA.; New Law Relative to Docks and Arsenals Prospects of the Cass-Herran Treaty. Arrival of Commodore Vanderbilt's Agents at San Juan.

docs.lead_paragraph: By the Star of the West we have advices from Aspin wall to the 5th inst. The New-Orleans, Havana and Aspin wall steamship Grunada, on her last trip, landed D. B. ALLEN, son-in-law of Com. VANDERBILT, and his brother; also, W. R. C WEBSTER and Mr. GOTTEL, their interpreter, with $80,000 in hard cash, at San Juan del Norte, on the 28th ultime.

docs.snippet: SUSPECTED BERGLARS AND A RECEIVER ARRESTED--PRACTICAL AMALGAMATION.--A few weeks ago, the dwelling-house No. 32 Macdongal-street was broken into, and about $700 worth of jewelry and silver-ware stolen. Two policemen saw two colored men come out of...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUSPECTED BERGLARS AND A RECEIVER ARRESTED--PRACTICAL AMALGAMATION.--A few weeks ago, the dwelling-house No. 32 Macdongal-street was broken into, and about $700 worth of jewelry and silver-ware stolen. Two policemen saw two colored men come out of the house, and attempted to arrest them, but the burglars, it will be remembered, discharged their revolvers--probably not loaded, as no harm was done--frightened away the officers, and then made good their escape.

docs.snippet: REMARKABLE EVENT-In the City court, yesterday, Mr. JOHN BENNETT, livery stable keeper, South Sixth street, Claimed that he had been damaged to the amount of $ 3,000 by the overflowing of a cistern under an engine house, which undermined his premles....
docs.lead_paragraph: REMARKABLE EVENT-In the City court, yesterday, Mr. JOHN BENNETT, livery stable keeper, South Sixth street, Claimed that he had been damaged to the amount of $ 3,000 by the overflowing of a cistern under an engine house, which undermined his premles. He brought suit,. and the Jury rendered a verdict for defendants.

docs.snippet: WHITEWASHING THE DISTILLERY STABLES.--The Board of Health yesterday adopted the majority report of the Swill-milk Committee of the Board of Aldermen, thus giving the official approval of the City authorities to the stump-tail nuisance.
docs.lead_paragraph: WHITEWASHING THE DISTILLERY STABLES.--The Board of Health yesterday adopted the majority report of the Swill-milk Committee of the Board of Aldermen, thus giving the official approval of the City authorities to the stump-tail nuisance.
